title: NDP 2026: Showtime
description: The show is live. 40,000 in the stands, millions watching from home. Then the livestream starts buffering. You have 20 minutes before the fireworks finale. The whole nation is watching.

software-engineer.title: Fix the Livestream
software-engineer.instruction: The video is freezing every few seconds and millions of viewers are complaining. The video processing pipeline is the bottleneck. You have exactly 20 minutes before the fireworks. What do you do?
software-engineer.hint: When millions are watching and time is very short, a solution that works for everyone at lower quality beats a risky perfect fix that might fail during deployment.

options.label: Drop stream quality from 4K to 1080p. Everyone gets a smooth experience instantly, but the committee specifically wanted 4K for the drone formation coming up.
Start extra processing machines to share the workload. Risky — it takes 10 of your 20 minutes to set up and test, but if it works, quality stays perfect.
Switch to a backup content delivery network with better capacity in Southeast Asia. Quick to do but you lose some viewer statistics in the process.
Turn on smart streaming that gives each viewer the best quality their internet can handle. Some see 4K, some see lower quality, but nobody's video freezes.

data-scientist.title: Predict Viewer Drop-off
data-scientist.instruction: Viewers are leaving the livestream because of the buffering. Based on the viewer count trend over the last 4 minutes (in thousands), predict how many viewers (in thousands) will still be watching in 5 minutes if nothing is done. This tells the team how urgently they need to act.
data-scientist.hint: Look at how many viewers are leaving per minute. The number leaving each minute is roughly the same — extend that trend 5 minutes forward.

cloud-engineer.title: Reroute the Traffic
cloud-engineer.instruction: The main streaming servers are overwhelmed. You need to spread the load across backup servers around the region. Put these steps in the right order. One wrong move and the stream goes offline completely.
cloud-engineer.hint: Never move traffic to a destination you haven't checked is ready. Always verify, prepare, then gradually shift — never all at once.

items.label: Check that all backup servers in other regions are healthy and ready to receive traffic
Update the internet address book to point traffic to multiple regions
Pre-load the backup servers with the latest video segments so viewers don't hit empty servers
Move 30% of traffic to backup servers first as a test run
Once confirmed stable, spread traffic evenly across all healthy servers
